Free coffee is available in the coffee shop and cafeteria every Monday! There is a free employee fitness center available to all staff. If you need a few minutes to decompress, they have relaxation rooms available. This year they added a massage chair to every nursing unit break room. They give every employee a $50 gift certificate for the holidays to use at a local small business to help our community. I used the tuition reimbursement to get my Masters... the tuition reimbursement is $7,000 every year, plus $1,000 for CEU credits every year! The parking is ON CAMPUS! job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Holyoke, MA
pros:
The response of everyone at HMC to Covif-19 has been amazing. When it was apparent there would be a PPE shortage, our CEO sent a companywide email asking for employees to start finding supplies... and they sure did. Every nurse that works on the floors was provided with a respirator mask! He has also secured donations of other PPE. Administration has been in the Command Center every day, adjusting how we work as new information is learned, correcting problems, and keeping employees updated.  They purchased scrubs for all of us to wear while at work, so we don't have to bring potentially contaminated scrubs home. They set up a system to wash the scrubs for us so we can pick up a clean set each day we work. They are providing free hotel rooms to staff that need to isolate from their families at home. Floor managers, clinical support staff, and charge nurses have been more available and supportive, (and they're already pretty available and supportive at baseline). A new ICU, new sections with negative pressure rooms, and entire new floors were created by this team to handle the influx of patients who need our care. Two floors were created in this hospital to house residents of the Holyoke Soldier's Home when it wasn't safe for them to stay there during this pandemic.

Other Pros:  Supportive environment, Patient focused care,  Cafeteria makes great food.
cons: The pay isn't comparable to other hospitals in the area

pros: The majority of people who work here are awesome people. They are friendly and their main priority is to provide excellent patient care. It is awesome to walk down the hall and be greeted with a smile and a wave from basically anyone who works in the hospital.
cons: The pay for a RN is significantly lower than other hospitals. I am talking $7 per hr lower. There is also no such thing as a raise. Even with your "annual review" you do not receive a raise. The only time you might get a raise is with a cost of living raise. Which you may or may not receive one year. They do have a "clinical ladder" program where you can join tons of committees, participate in hospital events, train employees, and construct education programs. Then you have to write an essay about all of these things and fill out a chart to submit to a committee to "apply" to prove you deserve an extra dollar per hour. LOL. In additions, like most of healthcare within the US, we are always short-staffed. No surprise there. People will leave positions and management just decides to not refill this positions, leaving us even more short-staffed than baseline. Then when a pandemic hits, they are overworking nurses even more than usual while not providing any additional pay, benefits, or hazard pay. They have the RNs doing the role of respiratory therapist, RN, phlebotomist, speech and hearing, and CNA. All to reduce other people's exposure. RNs are the sacrificial lamb and we get paid poorly. The nurses stay because we care about the patients and we would never abandon them, especially at a time like this. Unfortunately, we are taken advantage of all year, but it is worse at a time like this.

pros: I am very thankful to be part of such a community. The plethora of "thank you" letters we receive,  the "success stories" of our patients and the general sense of accomplishment we all feel at the end of each day are  enough to keep us going. review_title: CAUSE FOR CONCERN HOLYOKE MEDICAL CENTER AND THE PHLEBOTOMY DEPT.
pros: They hired me before I received my certification.
cons: Holyoke Medical Center retaliated against me and terminated my employment because I was a whistleblower. I began bringing attention to the many violations that I witnessed being performed by the staff within the organization. I worked there for 1 year and my time as an employee could best be described as stressful and miserable. I would never recommend this hospital to anyone considering employment there. I have witnessed numerous unsafe and unsanitary work conditions that are rarely, if ever, addressed by management. The Phlebotomy Department is extremely cliquey and the staff are unhappy due to the low wages, no advancement opportunities, bullying, and favoritism. Overtime and desired shifts are reserved for members of the current clique in power although no one seems to last long as they have a very high turnover rate. The current management has no managerial experience, no training, and zero accountability and still was promoted due to favoritism of management who has since been fired for sexual harassment of a former employee. There is a general unprofessional work environment causing a lack of communication and accountability which makes working there very stressful. I would describe it as toxic place to work. I have witnessed staff tampering with patients blood work by opening 3 tubes and pouring them into 1 (which is not permitted) for A Type Screen. Staff at Holyoke Medical Center rarely wash their hands after drawing patients blood. Staff rarely clean the lab chairs after blood draws. Gloves are limited. Tourniquets are reused on multiple patients during blood draws. No goggles are provided to the staff. No splash guards are available to protect staff while labeling patient specimens. Needle sharp containers are overflowing as are the garbage cans with blood soiled gauze. Staff uses larger gauged needles to fill the tubes of blood faster causing discomfort to the patients. Improper use of heel sticks by staff to perform finger sticks on patients to draw blood faster which is not commonly acceptable or proper procedure. Patients should exercise caution when visiting Holyoke Medical Center as patient safety and care seem not to be a priority to this hospital. Confidential and personal patient files are poorly handled and are often left unattended for anyone to read/browse. Staff openly discuss patients information in common areas of the hospital. If your blood work is not ordered STAT it will be left unattended and vulnerable to being placed in the rack inside a clear opened plastic box in the blood draw room for an extended period of time. Tubes of blood are often mishandled and go missing. Extensive wait times can be expected due to call outs by staff. Staff members are often on their cell phones, or hiding in the back ignoring the patients waiting in the lobby or take extended lunch and or coffee breaks. I have witnessed a employee smoking her vape pen inside of the phlebotomy laboratory in front of other employees in violation of state law and company policy. This woman happened to be friends with the current management so she was never reprimanded. This hospital is infested with cockroaches on the top and bottom floor predominantly. They run across the lab floor like kids in a candy store. Staff sometimes catches the insects in containers used for urine samples and leave them on the desk of management. They are just ignored and business goes on as usual. Holyoke Medical Center has an increasingly high turnover rate for hospitals in the state. The Laboratory Department management was a predator who abused his power and position of authority. He was terminated from Holyoke Medical Center and his previous place of employment for sexual harassment, violating company policy, and for poaching a female staff members personal phone number from the employee files for his own use. Both the male and female management were demoted and are currently no longer with the company. Six employees were also fired within the 1 year I was employed. Many were terminated due to issues regarding errors made labeling a patients blood sample. I alerted Human Resources and Administration of the multiple disturbing events I had personally witnessed. I submitted multiple written and verbal complaints. They were ignored and shortly after I was removed from the daily employee schedule reducing my hours to zero. I believe that qualifies as workplace retaliation. They then stopped scheduling me for all future shifts and I was told to not return back to the Phlebotomy Department. Retaliation is fairly commonplace at Holyoke Medical Center. I understand that every hospital is a business but their daily practices which happen frequently are a wake up call and should raise concern for the community which it serves and general public safety at large. I felt it my duty and obligation to alert anyone thinking of using this hospital to know the truth. Hope this makes a difference.
